title: WCAS LEGAL_ST 376-0-22 Topics in Legal Studies
topic: Law and the Origins of American Capitalism

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Legal_St 376-0-22 "Law and the Origins of American Capitalism" Susan Gaunt Stearns (Spring 2017)

This course examines the intertwined development of American law and American capitalism from the nation's founding until the turn of the 20th century. It will examine the relationship between law and economic activity in a variety of forms, from counterfeiting to slavery.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students will analyze and evaluate primary and secondary sources related to the theme of law and capitalism.
Students will analyze how both economic activity and the law changed over the course of the time period under discussion.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Stephen Mihm, A Nation of Counterfeiters
William Novak, The People's Welfare: Law and Regulation in Nineteenth -Century America
John Fabian Witt, The Accidental Republic: Crippled Workingmen, Destitute Widows, and the Remaking of American Law
Jane Kamensky, The Exchange Artist: A Tale of High Flying Speculation and America's First Banking Collapse
Edward E. Baptist, The Half that Has Never Been Told: Slavery and the Making of American Capitalism
